abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Sixth Agricultural
            Development Bank Project for Pakistan was unsatisfactory.
            The project did not fully achieve its principal objectives,
            its impact on institutional development was negligible,
            sustainability is unlikely, and both the Bank and Borrower
            performed satisfactorily. Several lessons can be learned
            from this project. First, it is of critical importance to
            have stable, strong, and capable leadership on a continuing
            basis. Second, institution building is a slow process.
            Third, it is preferable to have agricultural banks that are
            closely integrated into a country's financial system
            rather than institutions given such a specialized position
            as ADBP. Fourth, the Bank should take a firmer position
            regarding the financial performance of the banks, insisting
            on satisfactory results as a precondition for (continued)
            lending. Fifth, in designing repeater projects like the
            Agricultural Credit Project, it would have been desirable to
            avoid the overlap with the preceding sixth project. Finally,
            poor profitability of agricultural banks in general, and
            ADBP in particular, is the result of administered,
            subsidized interest rates to borrowers which do not pass on
            the full cost of lending.
